Along with increasing vector range, climate change has also extended the habitat or reach of organisms that cause adverse health effects. For example, the incidence of coccidioidomycosis, a fungal disease endemic in the Southwest U.S. has been associated with a number of outdoor occupations and has increased substantially from 1998–2011.
[89,92,119–130] Drought-ridden areas may lead to outdoor workers breathing more windborne dusts with various toxicities and possibly containing harmful organisms.
